risinfo.chaptertitle: 1. An Introduction to Clinical and Diagnostic Interviewing: Fundamental Skills and Key Issues

sect1.title: The Common Factors Approach in Interviewing and Psychotherapy
sect1.para: Common factors in interviewing and psychotherapy

entry.para: Alliance: The therapeutic alliance therapeutic alliance is a collaborative working relationship that is comprised of an emotionally charged bond between the therapist and patient and agreement about the goals and tasks of therapy. A positive therapeutic relationship is essential to the success experienced by most clients

Empathy: Empathy Empathy is the ability to perceive and understand a client’s feelings “as if” the clinician was experiencing them personally and to communicate that accurate understanding to the client. Conveying empathy makes the client feel understood and enhances trust, strengthening the therapeutic alliance

Positive regard/affirmation: Conveying warmth warmth and acceptance of the client acts as a positive reinforcement for their participation in therapy and affirms their self-worth. Demonstrating positive regard facilitates their tendency to grow and meet their potential

Congruence/genuineness: Being authentic authentic and transparent with clients allows the therapist and client to reflect on problematic mind states with openness, deepening security in the therapy relationship

Expectations/hope: Clients formulate formulate expectations about psychotherapy based on the therapist’s explanation of the presenting problem and the treatment they present, and these expectations influence their progress. It is therefore important to provide clients with an explanation of their difficulties that the client accepts, and a treatment plan that is consistent with the explanation provided

Goal consensus/collaboration: It is a therapist’s responsibility responsibility to create a well-defined and culturally imbedded treatment plan that the client accepts. To promote collaboration on behalf of the client, therapists can encourage them to complete homework assignments and educate them on the importance of cooperation in therapy

Therapist effects: Some therapists consistently achieve better outcomes with clients than other therapists regardless of the type of treatment administered. More effective therapists possess strong facilitative interpersonal skills, tend to self-reflect about their practice, and are able to form strong alliances across a range of clients

sect2.title: Establishing a Therapeutic Alliance
sect2.para: At the most basic level, for clients to participate effectively in psychotherapy, it is vital that they feel at ease with the clinician, which facilitates the clients in disclosing and discussing intimate and personal details of their lives. Remember that, initially, many clients do not know what to expect from psychotherapy or from the clinician. Clients are faced with the task of being expected to reveal private and emotionally sensitive information to a veritable stranger. As such, they may be apprehensive, embarrassed, or downright terrified at the beginning of the first interview. Some clients find it difficult to ask for help because of the stigma associated with mental disorders and their treatment. Others may have been in psychotherapy before but did not find it useful, and therefore, they are cautious and skeptical of what the clinician can offer. Table 1.3
Aspects of a cultural formulation cultural formulation

entry.para: Cultural identity of the individual: Describe the individual’s racial, ethnic, or cultural reference groups that may influence his or her relationship with others, access to resources, and developmental and current challenges, conflicts, or predicaments. For immigrants and racial or ethnic minorities, the degree and kinds of involvement with both the culture of origin and the host culture or majority culture should be noted separately. Language abilities, preferences, and patterns of use are relevant for identifying difficulties with access to care, social integration, and the need for an interpreter. Other clinically relevant aspects of identity may include religious affiliation, socioeconomic background, personal and family places of birth and growing up, migrant status, and sexual orientation

Cultural conceptualizations of distress: Describe the cultural constructs that influence how the individual experiences, understands, and communicates his or her symptoms or problems to others. These constructs may include cultural syndromes, idioms of distress, and explanatory models or perceived causes. The level of severity and meaning of the distressing experiences should be assessed in relation to the norms of the individual’s cultural reference groups. Assessment of coping and help-seeking patterns should consider the use of professional as well as traditional, alternative, or complementary sources of care

Psychosocial stressors and cultural features of vulnerability and resilience: Identify key stressors and supports in the individual’s social environment (which may include both local and distant events) and the role of religion, family, and other social networks in providing emotional, instrumental, and informational support. Social stressors and social supports vary with cultural interpretation of events, family structure, developmental tasks, and social context. Levels of functioning, disability, and resilience should be assessed in light of the individual’s cultural reference groups

Cultural features of the relationship between the individual and the clinician: Identify differences in culture, language, and social status between an individual and the clinician that may cause difficulties in communication and may influence diagnosis and treatment. Experiences of racism and discrimination in the larger society may impede establishing trust and safety in the clinical diagnostic encounter. Effects may include problems eliciting symptoms, misunderstanding of the cultural and clinical significance of symptoms and behaviors, and difficulty establishing or maintaining the rapport needed for an effective clinical alliance

Overall cultural assessment: Summarize the implications of the components of the cultural formulation cultural formulation identified in earlier sections of the outline for diagnosis and other clinically relevant issues or problems as well as appropriate management and treatment intervention

sect2.title: Demonstrating Empathy
sect2.para: A key factor in establishing a strong therapeutic alliance alliance and a fundamental skill for any clinician is the ability to empathize with another person’s experiences and convey such empathy through validation and understanding. Empathy is the ability to perceive and understand a client’s feelings “as if” the clinician was experiencing them and to communicate that accurate understanding to the client (Faust, 1998 ). Always keep in mind that no two clients are the same and the clinician should be attuned to the subtleties of the client’s thoughts, feelings, behaviors, and lived experiences. A distinction to be made is that empathy is understanding, not sympathy. By responding empathically, the client knows that the clinician is accepting accepting , understanding, and joining his or her “world” without judgment, rather than just “feeling bad” for the client (Johnston et al., 1998 ). This empathic understanding enhances trust and increases the likelihood that the client will reveal intimate details of his or her life, possibly details that the client has never previously revealed to anyone.

Empathy can be conveyed in many ways (e. g., nonverbal behaviors, such as listening attentively, nodding, showing a concerned facial expression; verbal communications of understanding and support) allowing the clinician to choose a style that is most comfortable for him or her. Other important strategies for conveying empathy and validation include an appropriate tone of voice, time and rate of comments and questions, and the area of questioning. When used correctly, these strategies can be critical in conveying warmth and understanding.

sect2.title: Positive Regard/Affirmation
Congruence/Genuineness
sect2.para: Congruence Congruence is an aspect of the therapeutic relationship that is characterized by the therapist being genuinely and mindfully present in their interactions with clients. This requires personal awareness and authenticity on behalf of the therapist and the ability to effectively convey this to their client (Kolden et al., 2018 ). To foster congruence, the therapist should be accessible, approachable, and as transparent as they reasonably can be, rather than hiding behind stereotypical roles. Congruence is essential for the transference of empathy and positive regard and allows the therapist and client to recognize and reflect on problematic mind states with openness, thereby deepening security in the therapy relationship (Kolden et al., 2018 ). In this way, congruence/genuineness is a crucial aspect of the therapeutic alliance.

sect2.title: Having Shared Expectations/Providing Hope
sect2.para: Our expectations surrounding situations influence our experiences. As such, a client’s beliefs about the effectiveness of psychotherapy are likely to contribute to or hinder their progress. In psychotherapy, the therapist’s explanation of a client’s disorder and the treatment plan they proscribe shape the client’s expectations. It is important to provide clients with an explanation for their difficulties that is accepted by the client, and treatment that is consistent with that explanation (Wampold & Imel, 2015 ). Therefore, the therapist must carefully consider the client’s cultural background background and how this may influence their beliefs and attitude toward mental disorders. As the client comes to believe that participating in and completing the tasks of therapy will be helpful in coping with their symptoms, their expectation that they have the ability to do what is needed to help themselves increases, which results in improvements. The client’s belief that their treatment will provide new perspectives, change, and the possibility for growth is also critically important for the establishment of trust. If the clinician can consistently model and demonstrate this stance of hopefulness, clients will likely experience the freedom and security to more fully disclose and work on their problems.

sect2.title: Goal Consensus/Collaboration
sect2.para: Another key common factor that influences psychotherapy outcomes is goal consensus and collaboration between the therapist and client. As previously mentioned, to maximize success, the therapist should create a well-defined and culturally imbedded treatment plan with specific goals that are understood and agreed upon by both the therapist and client. Tryon and Winograd ( 2011 ) caution clinicians against pushing their own agenda, advise clinicians to give the client ample opportunities opportunities to share their input on the objectives and their progress regularly throughout the course of treatment, and to be prepared to make adjustments to the treatment plan according to the client’s feedback. To foster collaboration, they suggest educating clients about the importance of their cooperation in making progress by sharing results of research studies and by encouraging them to complete homework assignments and other agreed-upon tasks.

sect2.title: Therapist Effects
sect2.para: Variation in treatment outcomes can be partly attributed to therapist effects. Some therapists are more skilled than others, even if they are delivering the same treatments (Laska et al., 2014 ). Therapists who possess better facilitative interpersonal skills, provide an emotionally activating relationship, and are able to form strong alliances with a diverse range of clients achieve better outcomes. As such, working on yourself is always an ongoing area for professional development development . Actively using the approaches and strategies outlined in this section will enable cultivation of a strong therapeutic alliance that paves the way for more positive results.
